sections.title: Introduction
sections.content:
Related articles

- Session lock
- List of applications/Security#Screen lockers

Slock, or the "Simple X display locker", is a display locker for X that aims to be minimal, fast, and lightweight.[1].

sections.title: Installation
sections.content: Install the slock or slock-gitAUR package.

sections.title: Configuration
sections.content: Configuration is done by editing the config.h header file and then recompiling the package. After configuration you should create a package.

sections.title: Usage
sections.content:
Simply run slock to lock the screen. You can also provide an argument to be run after the screen has been locked:

```
$ slock cmd [arg ...]
```

To unlock the screen, just type your password.

sections.title: Lock on suspend
sections.content:
Create the following service which locks the screen.

```
/etc/systemd/system/slock@.service
```

```
[Unit]
Description=Lock X session using slock for user %i
Before=sleep.target

[Service]
User=%i
Environment=DISPLAY=:0
ExecStart=/usr/bin/slock

[Install]
WantedBy=sleep.target
```

Enable the slock@user.service systemd unit for it to take effect for the username user.

sections.title: Block VT switching and prevent killing X
sections.content: slock recommends blocking VT switching so that the screen lock cannot be bypassed. For the same reason, slock recommends preventing users from killing the X server. See Xorg#Block TTY access and Xorg#Prevent a user from killing X.
